In Julia, Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

In Julia, you can use the `Dates` package to work with dates and datetimes. Here's how you might write a function named `add_yearmonth` that adds a new column to your DataFrame called 'ym':

Firstly, add the Dates and DataFrames packages if not already done:
```julia
using Pkg; Pkg.add("Dates")
using Dates, DataFrames
```
Then define the function `add_yearmonth`:
```julia
function add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
    df[:ym] = map((x) -> Dates.year(x)*100 + Dates.month(x), df.dt)
end
```
You can then apply this function to your DataFrame like so:
```julia
add_yearmonth(df)
```
This will add a new column `ym` to your DataFrame, where each entry is the year and month of the corresponding DateTime in the df column. 

Note that you should replace 'df' with your actual dataframe.
